Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: First I need to understand the normative rules clearly from Part 1 The process has a strict sequence Application Received Credit Check Risk Assessment Loan Decision Inform Applicant If Approved Finalize Documentation Close Case There are specific ordering constraints like Credit Check before Risk Assessment and so on

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: Looking at each case in the event log

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 1 The activities follow the exact order After Application Received it does Credit Check first then Risk Assessment Loan Decision approved Inform Applicant Finalize Documentation then Close Case No steps skipped or out of order So this seems compliant with normative rules

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 2 Here after Application Received there s a Risk Assessment before the required Credit Check That violates the ordering rule where Credit Check must come before Risk Assessment Then despite the rejection Finalize Documentation is done before closing the case which is explicitly not allowed for rejections Both these actions are normative violations

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 3 The sequence seems okay Application Received Credit Check after a delay 24 hours other steps follow in order However Credit Check is delayed beyond the recommended time window 24 hours and Informing Applicant happens much later than 48 hours after decision Also there s no Follow up Call mentioned as per desiderata These are all desideratum violations because they don t meet the timing recommendations or optional best practices

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Now for part 2 about desiderata Case 3 has several of these issues but none that break the strict rules So I need to note those as suboptimal behaviors

Name: Abductive Reasoning - IND
Text: Lastly possible justifications could include system constraints like in Case 3 maybe there was a backlog or errors in process handling causing violations However without more context it s hard to justify normative rule breaches directly
